_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

How a master thief relies on rough groun: A master thief relies on inaccessible riverlands or rugged mountains
How a master thief relies on thick cover: A master thief relies on thick grass, thick trees, a blind spot, or a large dense wood
How a master thief relies on powerful in: A master thief relies on rulers or their ministers
How a master thief pays bribes (a causal: A master thief is rich, affluent, and wealthy
How a master thief acts alone (a causal: A master thief carries out robbery all alone
How a bad mendicant relies on rough grou: A bad mendicant has unethical conduct by way of body, speech, and mind
How a bad mendicant relies on thick cove: A bad mendicant has wrong view, heâ€™s attached to an extremist view
How a bad mendicant relies on powerful i: A bad mendicant relies on rulers or their ministers
How a bad mendicant pays bribes (a causa: A bad mendicant receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick
How a bad mendicant acts alone (a causal: A bad mendicant dwells alone in the borderlands and visits families there to get material possessions.
